section_summaries.title: ZÁKON ze dne 24. ledna 1997
section_summaries.summary: The law from January 24, 1997, regulates peaceful nuclear energy, liability for nuclear damage, and insurance for operators in the Czech Republic.
Section 32 of Czech law addresses nuclear liability, stating civil code provisions apply only if not overridden by international treaties.
Czech law assigns nuclear damage liability to operating license holders, treating multiple facilities under one operator as a single entity for accountability.
§ 34 outlines that compensation for nuclear damage in Czech law follows the Civil Code and regulations in effect at the time of the incident.
§ 34 defines "nuclear damage" in Czech law, detailing prevention costs and the State Office for Nuclear Safety's regulatory role.
Section 35 of Czech law defines nuclear operators' liability limits for damages from nuclear incidents, outlining their legal responsibilities.
Section 35 sets liability limits for nuclear operators: 8 billion CZK for energy facilities and 2 billion CZK for others and transport.
Nuclear operators in Czechia must secure liability insurance or financial guarantees for nuclear damage, with specific conditions set by authorities.
The state guarantees compensation for nuclear damage claims not covered by insurance, retaining rights to seek reimbursement from license holders.
Czech law sets a 3-year claim limit for nuclear damage, with a 10-year max, and requires license holders to notify affected areas.
Section § 45 addresses amendments to Czech income tax law regarding nuclear operators' liability and insurance for nuclear damage.
Section 45 amends Czech law on civil liability for nuclear damage, clarifying nuclear operators' responsibilities and insurance requirements.
Section 45 outlines financial provisions for nuclear energy in Czech law, addressing income from radioactive waste storage and tax exemptions.
§ 45 discusses § 26(8) of the Czech Atomic Act, highlighting nuclear energy use regulations and operators' legal liabilities.
